channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Doritos, M&Ms Could Be Forced to Include Warnings in Texas
item.description: A Texas bill on the verge of becoming law would require labels on packaged food from Skittles to Mountain Dew that warn about ingredients “not recommended for human consumption” by other countries.
item.dc:creator: Will Kubzansky, Rachel Cohrs Zhang

item.title: Trump Blasts Rand Paul as ‘Crazy’ for Resisting Tax-Cut Bill Over Debt Limit
item.description: President Donald Trump attacked fiscal conservative Rand Paul as “crazy” Tuesday morning as he pressed reluctant Republican senators to move forward swiftly with his massive tax and spending package.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Senator Rand Paul

item.title: Bessent Says China Has a ‘Choice’ on Whether or Not to Be a Reliable Partner
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Beijing has a choice on whether or not to be a dependable partner with the rest of the world, reiterating that China needs to shift to a more consumption-led economy to help ease global imbalances.
item.dc:creator: Annmarie Hordern, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: Starmer Weighs UK Military Request to Back 3.5% NATO Spend Goal
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer is considering a Ministry of Defence request to back NATO’s proposed new military spending target of 3.5% of national output by 2032, a major new pledge that would test the UK’s already stretched public finances.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Alex Wickham, Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer speaks to British and Albanian troops during a visit to Berzite military museum in Tirana, Albania.

item.title: Penn Wins Dismissal of Antisemitism Lawsuit by Jewish Students
item.description: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit against University of Pennsylvania filed by Jewish students over antisemitism, ruling they failed to show the Ivy League school engaged in intentional discrimination.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: Students on the University of Pennsylvania campus in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, US, on Friday, Dec. 8, 2023. Penn was sued by a pair of students who claim the campus was a hotbed of antisemitism even before Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7.

item.title: NATO Is Pushing Europeans for Fivefold Boost to Air Defenses
item.description: NATO is asking European member states to expand ground-based air-defense capabilities fivefold as the alliance races to fill a key gap in response to the threat of Russian aggression, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber, Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: IRIS-T SLM air defense systems in Panker, Germany. Photographer: Gregor Fischer/Getty Images

item.title: Kirchner’s Return Risks Dividing Opposition in Boon for Milei
item.description: Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner is back on Argentina’s political scene for the first time since President Javier Milei took office, set to challenge the libertarian and contest power within her own Peronist party in an upcoming local vote.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner Photographer: Tomas Cuesta/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Carney’s Budget Delay Adds to Economic Uncertainty in Canada, Analysts Say
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney’s decision to delay Canada’s budget until later this year increases economic uncertainty but isn’t likely to spark worries among investors, say a majority of economists in a Bloomberg survey.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg, Dana Morgan

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney.

item.title: French Senate Amends Fast-Fashion Bill to Target Shein, Temu
item.description: French senators are seeking to sharpen planned legislation aimed at regulating fast fashion to target sellers of ultra-cheap clothing such as Chinese-founded Shein Group Ltd. and Temu.
item.dc:creator: Ania Nussbaum

media:content.media:description: Packages from Shein in Santiago, Chile.

item.title: Iran Says US Proposal for Nuclear Deal Is Ambiguous and Unclear
item.description: A US proposal for a nuclear deal with Iran contains “many ambiguities and questions” that the Islamic Republic plans to address in the coming days, the country’s Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi told state TV on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: An Iranian flag near Iran's Bushehr nuclear power plant.

item.title: Israel’s Gaza Push Spurs Europe Leaders to Turn on Netanyahu
item.description: Some of Israel’s most loyal supporters in Europe are increasingly speaking out against the war in Gaza, with several nations, including Germany, considering trade sanctions and curbs on arms sales.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: A man looks for survivors following an Israeli strike in the northern Gaza Strip on June 2.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Attacked Crimean Bridge as Traffic Halted
item.description: Ukraine said it attacked the Crimean Bridge with explosives as Russia closed traffic on the route linking the annexed Black Sea peninsula with the Russian mainland.
item.dc:creator: Kateryna Chursina

media:content.media:description: Locals survey the damage to the underwater support structures of the Crimean Bridge in Crimea, Kherson Oblast, Ukraine, in a photo released by the Security Service of Ukraine, on June 3.

item.title: Hungary Police Ban Pride Parade in Showdown Over Culture War
item.description: Hungarian authorities barred the annual Pride parade on the streets of Budapest in the latest salvo of Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s escalating culture war before elections.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon

media:content.media:description: Police officers watch the crowd during the annual Pride event in Budapest, in 2023.

item.title: Media Groups Probed by FTC Over Coordinating Boycott Claims
item.description: The US Federal Trade Commission is investigating whether more than a dozen media and advertising groups have illegally colluded to boycott online content alleged to be hateful, false or misleading, according to people familiar with the matter and a document seen by Bloomberg News.
item.dc:creator: Josh Sisco, Kurt Wagner

media:content.media:description: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. The Trump administration dismissed two Democrats on the US Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday, in the latest move by the White House to assert control over US agencies.

item.title: UK Rushes to Save US Steel Tariff Deal Before Levies Double
item.description: The UK is pushing the US to remove tariffs on British steel exports in line with a deal struck last month, ahead of a planned blanket doubling of levies.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Mark Burton

media:content.media:description: Molten steel at a plant in Sheffield, UK. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

item.title: Dutch Prime Minister to Resign, Continue in Caretaker Role
item.description: Dutch Prime Minister Dick Schoof said his government would offer to resign and continue on in a caretaker role, setting the stage for a likely snap election.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom, Katharina Rosskopf

media:content.media:description: Dick Schoof in The Hague on June 3. Photographer: Laurens Van Putten/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Dutch Government Crisis Risks Slowing EU Decisions, ING CEO Says
item.description: The collapse of the Dutch government risks slowing decisions related to Europe’s planned investment spree, said ING Groep NV Chief Executive Officer Steven van Rijswijk.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Jacob, Steven Arons

media:content.media:description: Steven van Rijswijk

item.title: Trump Team Signals It Wants to Keep Control of Fannie, Freddie to Boost Budget
item.description: Signs are emerging that the Trump administration may be less willing to give up control of mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac than investors have bargained for, as policymakers scrounge for ways to close US budget gaps.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: A residential neighborhood in San Marcos, Texas.

item.title: China Criticizes EU’s Planned Curb on Medical Device Procurement
item.description: Beijing criticized as protectionist the European Union’s plan to curb Chinese medical device manufacturers’ access to public procurement contracts and vowed to take action to protect the country’s interests.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: A worker checks parts at a factory which produces medical endoscope lenses in Hangzhou, in China's eastern Zhejiang province on October 31, 2024. China's manufacturing output expanded this month for the first time since April, official data showed on October 31, rare good news for leaders struggling to boost activity in the world's second-largest economy. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT (Photo by STR/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: STR/AFP

item.title: Poland’s Tusk Heads Into Confidence Vote as Coalition Squabbles
item.description: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk is poised for a vote of confidence next week to shore up support for his government after the defeat of a political ally in Sunday’s presidential election stoked tension in the ruling coalition.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Bujnicki, Natalia Ojewska

media:content.media:description: TIRANA, ALBANIA - MAY 16: (L-R) Poland's Prime Minister Donald Tusk talks to the press after their meeting on May 16, 2025 in Tirana, Albania. The EPC brings together heads of state and government from the 27 European Union countries and 20 others. The items on today's agenda are security and democratic resilience, competitiveness and economic security, and mobility challenges and youth empowerment. (Photo by Leon Neal - Pool /Getty Images)

item.title: Russia’s Tumbling Crude Flows Drag Export Values to Two-Year Low
item.description: Four-week average crude flows fell by 170,000 barrels a day in the period to June 1
item.dc:creator: Julian Lee

media:content.media:description: Russia shipped 3.24 million barrels a day of crude in the four weeks to June 1.

item.title: South Africa’s High Court Rejects Bid to Halt Fuel Levy Increase
item.description: South Africa’s High Court dismissed a lawsuit filed by the opposition Economic Freedom Fighters party that sought to stop the government from raising fuel levies.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vecchiatto

media:content.media:description: A worker handles a diesel pump at a Texaco Inc. gas station in Pretoria, South Africa, on Wednesday, Nov. 3, 2021. South Africa's gasoline prices rose to a record on Wednesday, adding to inflationary pressures in an economy that imports almost all of its fuel.

item.title: South Korea’s Lee On Track to Win Election, Exit Poll Shows
item.description: South Korea’s main opposition Democratic Party nominee Lee Jae-myung is on track to win the presidential election, bringing to an end three-tumultuous years of conservative rule, according to an exit poll released soon after the voting ended.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung on June 2.

item.title: South Korea’s Kim Concedes Defeat to Lee in Presidential Election

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung, left, and his wife Kim Hye-gyeong at the Democratic Party’s election night event in Seoul, South Korea, on June 4.

item.title: Trump’s Dealmaking Style Won’t Sway Xi, Ex-White House Aide Says
item.description: A potential trade deal between the world’s top two economies hinges on Donald Trump and Xi Jinping overcoming core differences in their negotiation styles, former acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney said.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Zambia to Pay Farmers 3% More for Corn to Replenish Reserves
item.description: Zambia’s government will pay farmers 3% more for white corn this season than they were previously offered, even as officials project the harvest will more than double from last year’s 16-year low.
item.dc:creator: Taonga Mitimingi

media:content.media:description: White corn grain drops into a trailer during a harvest on a farm in Grootvlei, South Africa, on Tuesday, July 29, 2014. Meal from white corn is used to make a South African staple food known as pap, while the yellow variety is used for animal feed. Photographer: Dean Hutton

item.title: Saudi Arabia's Hurdles at Home Are Reshaping the Mideast Financial Order
item.description: Bankers and business leaders are shifting more attention toward the kingdom’s neighbors in the Gulf as it grapples with lower oil prices and weakening finances.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Martin, Dinesh Nair, Adveith Nair

media:content.media:description: Saudi Arabia needs to bring in foreign capital to continue spending.

item.title: All About Geert Wilders, the Far-Right Politician Who Brought Down Dutch Government
item.description: Far-right lawmaker Geert Wilders pulled his Freedom Party out of the Dutch government after coalition partners resisted his plans for tougher immigration rules. The government has lasted about a year, and early elections are now the likeliest outcome. While the Freedom Party is the biggest in parliament, its popularity has ebbed in recent months, and it’s not clear if Wilders will get to reprise his role of kingmaker in a future coalition.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: Freedom Party leader Geert Wilders Photographer: Sem Van Der Wal/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Kremlin Douses Imminent Putin Meeting With Trump and Zelenskiy
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin isn’t likely to meet US counterpart Donald Trump and Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelenskiy in the near future, the Kremlin said a day after Kyiv and Moscow held another round of inconclusive peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin Photographer: Yuri Kochetkov/Getty Images

item.title: Rising Security Risks Push Denmark to Quit EU's 'Frugal Four'
item.description: Denmark will break away from the alliance of frugal nations as it enters the next round of European Union budget negotiations, the Nordic country’s prime minister said, signaling a shift in priorities as security concerns dominate the bloc’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Sanne Wass

media:content.media:description: Mette Frederiksen, right, and the President of the European Parliament Roberta Metsola on June 3.
